title: Valtteri Bottas suffers crash in Mexican GP qualifying as Max Verstappen takes pole position
text:
Lewis Hamilton was given an unexpected leg-up towards claiming his sixth world title after Max Verstappen was stripped of pole position for the Mexican Grand Prix.

More than three hours after dominating qualifying, Verstappen was deemed to have failed to slow under the double yellow flags waved following Valtteri Bottas's heavy crash in the closing moments of the session.

Verstappen's demotion from first to fourth on the grid made space for Hamilton to go up from fourth to third – an important boost because the Briton needs to finish in the top three to have any chance of completing his championship defence here, with three rounds to spare.

A nightmare end to qualifying for Valtteri Bottas!



But thankfully he is okay 👍#MexicoGP 🇲🇽 #F1 pic.twitter.com/TakzoATo2i — Formula 1 (@F1) October 26, 2019

Valtteri Bottas crashed heavily during the final seconds of qualifying for the Mexican GP

The Finnish driver lost control of his car after running wide on the kerb at the final corner

Counter steering to avoid a spin, he slammed into the wall before careering into a barrier

Bottas appeared to be unhurt in the crash and is still set to start from sixth on Sunday

As a precaution he was taken to the F1 medical centre following his huge crash

Verstappen has only himself to blame for the penalty. The FIA had no intention of investigating his driving until his own bravado got the better of him.

Asked in the post-qualifying press conference if he had backed off, the Dutchman bristled: 'It didn't really look like it, did it? No.'

The foolhardy driver was then summoned by the stewards, looking at the data afresh, to explain his comments. They found him guilty of 'failure to slow for a yellow flag'.

Hamilton, who must outscore his Mercedes team-mate Bottas by 14 points to land the title, said: 'It's important that the FIA are really strict about the double yellow flags.

'Max didn't even need to go flat-out. He had already got pole with his previous lap.

'For all he knew, Valtteri could have been in the middle of the circuit. It's not great.'

Max Verstappen points to the first place plinth after taking pole for the Mexican Grand Prix

Verstappen is hoping to win the race for the third consecutive year in a row

There was controversy over Verstappen's pole though as he appeared to ignore yellow flags as a result of Bottas's crash at the Autodromo Hermanos Rodriguez circuit

Verstappen gives the thumbs up ahead of second placed Charles Leclerc (right) and his third placed Ferrari team-mate Sebastian Vettel

Fans look on at Verstappen during qualifying in the baseball stadium section of the circuit

After smashing into the wall at the final corner, Bottas, who is due to start sixth on the grid, said: 'My knees hit together – it was quite nasty. It was a nerve thing, so for a few minutes I couldn't feel my right knee but there is no pain now.'

The team were toiling to piece the car back together, but boss Toto Wolff said he was '90 per cent' confident they could do so without incurring any penalties.

Mercedes, meanwhile, have opened contract talks with Hamilton in an attempt to help him make more history.

His sixth title will lift him ahead of Juan Manuel Fangio and behind only Michael Schumacher in the list of motor-racing achievement. And, at 34, Hamilton probably has one giant contract to play for as he guns for titles seven and eight.

Mercedes are desperate to keep hold of him even it means granting a significant rise on his current £40million-a-year salary.

His contract runs until the end of next season, as do those of the other top drivers. They are all unwilling to rush into committing their futures beyond then with new regulations due to be introduced for 2021.

But Mercedes boss Toto Wolff revealed: 'Discussions with Lewis have slowly but surely started.

Lewis Hamilton could not keep up with Ferrari or Verstappen but was fourth fastest
description: JONATHAN McEVOY IN MEXICO CITY: Lewis Hamilton was given an unexpected leg-up towards claiming his sixth world title after Max Verstappen was stripped of pole position for the Mexican Grand Prix.
